course.subject: ENVR
course.name: Economics for Environmental Policy and Management
course.description: This course examines the economic theories behind environmental policy-making. Key concepts include externalities, common resources, market failures, polluter pays principle, and free market environmentalism. Several methods of non-market valuation of environmental goods are illustrated with real-world examples. Basic game theory is applied to understand the logic of collective actions. Throughout the course, the emphasis is on fostering an intuitive understanding of the topics from an economist’s point of view.
course.prerequisites: ECON 2103 OR ECON 2113 OR ECON 3113

reviews.author: Albert Liem
reviews.title: A really fun and insightful course!
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to the previous review for the content.

I have zero knowledge in economics as engineering student, just put fair amount of effort and you will do great!

The course is very fair in my opinion. Whether the course is good for you or not, really depends on your effort. You will be rewarded for it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Keith is really passionate about teaching. He will take time to answer student questions and even offer another half hour to stay after class to clear all doubts the student have. He is very friendly and happy to answer any questions, so don't be afraid to ask! He is a game theorist from Cambridge, so he knows his stuff
reviews.comment_grading: I would say it is really fair, i got A+ at the end. Read his lectures and practice his question, and you will do well :)
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair. There are no assignments, but there are written project and final presentation. I would say with regular meeting and effort, they are manageable.

reviews.author: usto.o
reviews.title: Terrible teaching and grading
reviews.comment_content: We examine the economic theories behind environmental policy-making. Key concepts include externalities, common resources, market failures, market-based policies for controlling pollution, and non-market valuation of environmental goods. Basic game theory is applied to understand the logic of collective actions. Throughout the course, the emphasis is on fostering an intuitive understanding of the topics from an economist’s point of view.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Terrible teaching.
Bad planning in teaching.
The slides are messy.
reviews.comment_workload:
Absolutely heavy workload.
Mid Term Exam, Final Exam, Participation and Group Seminar.

reviews.author: ghjkll
reviews.title: Easy mid-term and final!!! Good professor
reviews.comment_content:
Basic econ concept
How to apply econ theory into environmental policy
Introduction of the Game Theory

The content is interesting and inspiring.

Even engineering student can score a good grade in this course!!!
reviews.comment_teaching: Keith is nice and he is willing to answer students' questions. He encourages students to think and discuss more beyond the course content. Can't believe this was his first course (he is a new Prof.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Mid-term 15%
Final 40%
Participation 20%
Group project 25%

The mid-term and final are super easy!!! Pay attention in the lesson will be fine.

My term total overall 73/100, A range

The professor is generous in giving out good grade
reviews.comment_workload:
Depands on your groupmate. I carried my group.

Generally, the course has light workload
